vulnerability.name: Server header
vulnerability.description: The server header for the remote web server is: "nginx/1.10.0 (Ubuntu)".

http-response.body:
Computational Sensing Lab
  • Home
  • Research
  • Team
  • Publications
  • More
    • Datasets
    • Courses
    • Talks

The Indoor PM2.5 Investigation Report

This is the first big data report on the indoor PM2.5 pollution. Over 110,000 hours of data were collected from 7,700 locations in Beijing by over 400 vonluntary participants in a duration of four months in 2014-2015.

Download

Social Physical Sensing and Behavioral Consensus Incentivizing

This 20 minutes talk was given by Professor Lin Zhang in IoT Workshop at MIT Media Lab in October 2014.

It introduces our most recent research progress. A good starting point to navigate our research portfolio.

Watch it

SensorDB: an Open-source Platform for Big Sensory Data

Existing relational database suffers deteriorated performance as the volume of data scales due to the maintainance overhead of exponentially increasing indexing sets of existing data. While the noSQL database is not able to efficiently serve the spatial-temporal indexing which is critical for a large portion of sensory data.

We developed SensorDB, a semi-relational database to house very large spatial-temporal indexed sensory data sets. The software is made publicly available as an open-source software.

Read more

Challenges for you

Want to join our group as a Ph.D. of a master's student?

We invite you to try the challenging problems before you consider sending us emails.

There are one analytical challenging problem and one programing challenging problem.

Hack me if you can. :)

Try it!

Alumni

Placement of the alumni.

Read More

Important literatures in our fields.

Read More

Codes

Codes we are sharing.

Read More

Gallery

Something fun.

Read More

Research Projects

Our Team

«We are a highly motivated team.
We believe vision is even more important than skills.»

Lin Zhang
Associate Professor

Lin is the head of the laboratory, leading the research and education activities of the group.

He got all his degrees from Tsinghua University (BSc'98, MSc'01, Ph.D.'05) and is now an IEEE Senior Member.

Read more

Qiang Zhou
Hardware System Director

Qiang coordinates the hardware design and education activities of the laboratory

He has almost 20 years' experience in embedded hardware system design and manufacturing before he join the lab.

Read more

Junwei Fu
Database Specialist

Junwei is the big sensory data system architect. He has 10 years experience before he join the lab.

He is the developer of SensorDB, and is our sensory data platform administrator.

Read more

Shengnan Li
Administrative Associate

Shengnan is the administrative associate of the laboratory.

She takes care of the day-by-day operation of the team including budgeting and purchasing, and is the facilitator of internatioal collaborations.

Read more

Weiwei Jiang
Ph.D. Student

Weiwei is a sencond year Ph.D. student.

His research interest is matching algorithms on dynamic graph. Based on his research, he conducted the CountryRoad project that helped thousands of passengers to go home during the 2014 Chun Yun traffic.

Read more

Xiangxiang Xu
Ph.D. Student

Xiangxiang is a first year Ph.D. student.

His research interest is stochastic system parameterization based on sparse and unreliable samples. His research contributed significantly to our GotCha project for dynamic pollution source identification.

Read more

Yixin Zheng
Master's Student

Yixin is a third year master's student.

His research interests are time series interpolation and causality analysis. The results are utilized in the building vibration data and pollution data analysis.

Read more

Bolun Zhang
Master's Student

Bolun is a second year master's student.

His research interest is sensory data encapsulation and service structure. He is also the major contributor to the smart building platform of our laboratory.

Read more

The next one
will that be you?

We constantly seek for innovative and motivated students with clean thoughts, strong analytical skills, and the hacker spirit.

Thinkg you are the one? Come try our challenging problems.

Read more

vulnerability.name: Favicon identification failed
vulnerability.description: Favicon identification failed. If the remote site is using framework that is being exposed by its favicon, please send an email to w3af-develop@lists.sourceforge.net including this md5 hash "e1377e5305634805a944d25af699c118" and the name of the server or Web application it represents. New fingerprints make this plugin more powerful and accurate.

vulnerability.name: DNS wildcard
vulnerability.description: The target site has a DNS wildcard configuration, the contents of "http://ee.tsinghua.edu.cn/" are equal to the ones of "http://sensor.ee.tsinghua.edu.cn/".

vulnerability.name: Allowed HTTP methods
vulnerability.description: The URL "http://sensor.ee.tsinghua.edu.cn/" has the following enabled HTTP methods: *, GET, HEAD
vulnerability.long-description:
There are a number of HTTP methods that can be used on a webserver (`OPTIONS`, `HEAD`, `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE` etc.). Each of these methods perform a different function and each have an associated level of risk when their use is permitted on the webserver.
A client can use the `OPTIONS` method within a request to query a server to determine which methods are allowed.
Cyber-criminals will almost always perform this simple test as it will give a very quick indication of any high-risk methods being permitted by the server. The tool discovered that several methods are supported by the server.
vulnerability.fix-guidance:
It is recommended that a whitelisting approach be taken to explicitly permit the HTTP methods required by the application and block all others.
Typically the only HTTP methods required for most applications are `GET` and `POST`. All other methods perform actions that are rarely required or perform actions that are inherently risky. These risky methods (such as `PUT`, `DELETE`, etc) should be protected by strict limitations, such as ensuring that the channel is secure (SSL/TLS enabled) and only authorised and trusted clients are permitted to use them.

vulnerability.name: Click-Jacking vulnerability
vulnerability.description: The whole target has no protection (X-Frame-Options header) against Click-Jacking attacks
vulnerability.long-description:
Clickjacking (User Interface redress attack, UI redress attack, UI redressing) is a malicious technique of tricking a Web user into clicking on something different from what the user perceives they are clicking on, thus potentially revealing confidential information or taking control of their computer while clicking on seemingly innocuous web pages.
The server didn't return an `X-Frame-Options` header which means that this website could be at risk of a clickjacking attack. The `X-Frame-Options` HTTP response header can be used to indicate whether or not a browser should be allowed to render a page inside a frame or iframe. Sites can use this to avoid clickjacking attacks, by ensuring that their content is not embedded into other sites.
vulnerability.fix-guidance: Configure your web server to include an X-Frame-Options header.

w3af-run.error: The port '443' is not open on target sensor.ee.tsinghua.edu.cn
A BaseFrameworkException occurred while running hmap: "Connection failed to sensor.ee.tsinghua.edu.cn:80"
The xss plugin got an error while requesting "http://sensor.ee.tsinghua.edu.cn/". Reason: "HTTP timeout error"
The ssi plugin got an error while requesting "http://sensor.ee.tsinghua.edu.cn/". Reason: "HTTP timeout error"
